Fix finish_volume_migration() on SQLAlchemy 0.8.x

In SQAlchemy 0.8.x "Unconsumed column names" warning became
an exception, so refering to a non-existent column in insert()

really track changes to a model instance manually at all, because

subject: Change Message to extend built-in text type
commit_message:
Change Message to extend built-in text type

The original fix had misdiagnosed the underlying problem. For
background, this is how strings are processed by logging in py27:

1. The message object to be logged is added to the log record via
the "msg" attribute.

2. logging.LogRecord.getMessage does an isinstance(msg, basestring)
check.  If negative, the value of the "msg" attribute is replaced
by str(msg).  This was happening with openstack.common.gettexutils.
Message objects, since they did not extend either unicode or str
(py27).

3. The logging formatter combines metadata and the message to be
logged with the formatting string via a mod operation. If any of
the mod parameters are unicode objects, all of the other parameters
are promoted to unicode objects as part of the mod operation. If
the Message object in step 2 contains double-byte characters and
the default encoding is 'ascii' (which it usually is), the
promotion of the str object that was derived from the Message
object fails because it cannot process any non-ascii bytes.

Because the logging module and other string-processing modules
cannot be changed to accommodate Message objects, the only
alternative was to alter the Message class so that it extends
the built-in text type (unicode in py27) for double-byte
characters.

The implications of this change are that messages are no longer
translated when they are rendered; they are translated when
they are created and, from the user's perspective, they are
immutable, because the built-in text types are immutable.
The way to translate a Message instance is to call
its translate_into method; the Message instance that is returned
is the translated message, which itself can be translated.
In other words, translating a Message object does not alter
the underlying message ID.

closes bug 1225099
fixes bug 1229800

Change-Id: I9b67e57f4f9bea2883e76c7b20651879770d47bd

for extracting cell data from the row datum (and handling auto columns)
to the Cell class, into a separate method for easy extending. The
second is to make that extending possible by making the cell class
configurable in the DataTable's meta.

Those changes are supposed to make it easier to extend the DataTable
with new kinds of cells -- for example, cells that contain an editable
widget, a progress bar, an icon, etc. as well as make it easier to
modify the behavior of the auto columns -- for example, by making it
possible to have some of the multi_select checkboxes preselected. Those
changes would also make it easier to integrate DataTable with a Django
FormSet.

behavior, one has to make their own Row class and practically copy-paste

subject: Fix rare problem where external daemon is not started
commit_message:
Fix rare problem where external daemon is not started

Before daemon.py and external_process.py start a new process in an IP
namespace, they first check if the corresponding pid file exists. If it does,
they check if a process with that pid is running, and if so, and it's a Python
process with the uuid of the router or network in its command line, then they
consider the process to be already running and do not start it.

However they get this wrong if the pid file is stale, and if a rootwrap
process is running a command in the same IP namespace and it just happens to
have the same pid as in the stale file. This is very unlikely, but possible, and
results in the metadata namespace proxy not being started.

This patch prevents that by changing these modules so they do not mistake
commands with 'ip netns exec' as the process they are trying to start.

Fixes bug: 1223369
Change-Id: Id7c6eb5019ef61f87fd6edfa65ba2cb95fcd45dd

Running this through rechecks to collect data on the

******************

It appears that the issue in the repeated boot

giving the iscsi sub-system enough time for everyting

perform the connect/attach to /dev/disk-by-path we exceed the retries
before the iscsi mount is actually available.

This change will bump the retry count from 3 to 5, this seems a bit
excessive but it may help with debugging.  We're also adding a few

subject: Database migration cleanup I - Alembic translation
commit_message:
Database migration cleanup I - Alembic translation

This is the first in a series of patches to clean up the database
migrations in Ceilometer for the final Havana release. We plan to
move fully to Alembic in the first Icehouse milestone, but having
both Alembic and SA-migrate in the same codebase has been
confusing and caused a number of problems -- not the least of
which is that the Alembic migrations have not been tested in the
unit test gates.

This first patch does not remove the Alembic migrations. Rather, it
adds a single SA-migrate migration (016_alembic_translation) that
applies all of the migrations that were in the four Alembic migrations
as a single SA-migrate migration and then removes the alembic_version
database table.

The new migration does NOT support SQLite and so does not get run
by the **current** unit test case base class for the SQLAlchemy
storage driver (which simply calls migration.upgrade() on each test
case run on the SQLite database used in unittests). However, there
are gate tests that exercise all of the MySQL and PostgreSQL
SA-migrate migrations, so problems with the migration file should be
caught by those tests.

The next phase in this series will be the removal of Alembic from the
Ceilometer codebase for the final Havana release.

At the start of Icehouse, we'll essentially do an initial Alembic
migration that starts off from where Havana's SA-migrate-controlled
schema left off and remove SA-migrate from Ceilometer, going forward
only with Alembic. For stable/havana Ceilometer, contributors will
still need to submit SA-migrate migrations IFF their code changes the
database schema -- which being a stable branch should not happen except
in extreme circumstances.

Reference mailing list conversations here:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-September/014593.html

Change-Id: I1d6d5f601bdf03f43cb7e14768321120598d784c

subject: Safe db.api.compute_node_get_all() performance improvement
commit_message:
Safe db.api.compute_node_get_all() performance improvement

Scheduler stores the essential information for its work in DB in 3
tables: 'services', 'compute_nodes' and 'compute_node_stats'. For
each compute node, there is 1 record in 'services', 1 record in
'compute_nodes' and about 10 records in 'compute_node_stats'.

Each user request to scheduler to schedule an instance results
in a call to the db.api.compute_node_get_all() method which fetches
the information about all the compute nodes, their services and
corresponding stats in a single list.

There were 2 problems with the previous implementation of this
method. The first one was connected with network traffic: the
use of JOIN operation resulted in redundant informaion
returned from the DB in the resulting denormalized table. The
second one was a performance problem in the SQLAlchemy ORM's
implementation of data processing (slow model mappings in JOINs).

As we are just returning all the data from these 3 tables, we
have implemented a lower-level approach to solve these problems:
to reduce the network traffic, the new implementation of this
method fetches all the necessary data from 3 tables separately,
querying only for those columns that will be actually needed by
the scheduler ('created_at', 'deleted_at', 'updated_at' and
'deleted' columns get removed if the 'no_date_fields' parameter is
set to True). It then joins these tables manually, which allows
to avoid using the slow SQLAlchemy ORM's model mapping and thus
enables to speed up the whole process significantly.

We have tested the new implementation against the old one (with
the 'no_date_fields' parameter set to True). In our test example,
we have 10k services, 10k compute_nodes and 100k records in the
compute_node_stats (each key and each value is 15 characters in
length) database. The results are as follows:

+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| Approach                              | Time      | Traffic | Python memory |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| ORM joinedload (all columns)          | 15.58 sec | 26.8 MB | 579.9 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| ORM joinedload (filtered columns)     | n/a       | 17.2 MB | n/a           |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| core + manual join (all columns)      | 7.67 sec  | 9.4 MB  | 223.6 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+
| core + manual join (filtered columns) | 5.15 sec  | 5.6 MB  | 112.5 MB      |
+---------------------------------------+-----------+---------+---------------+

So our new implementation has 3 times better performance, uses 5 times
less traffic and yields 5 times less memory usage than the old one.

Test data was edited slightly here to reflect the real-world system
behaviour (services corresponding to compute nodes come with
binary='nova-compute').

subject: Race condition during init_host
commit_message:
Race condition during init_host

Solves race condition that potentially can lead to multiple instances
running from same disk on different hosts.
When compute service starts it checks whether managed instances
been evacuated to another host (in
manager._destroy_evacuated_instances). The time between this check and
when service appears to be active via servicegroup is a time when
instance can be evacuated to another host which will lead to duplicated
instances in the environment.

This patch solves it by keeping all the instances task_state in
"initing" until service initialization finished. In this way
evacuation of those instances can't be started.
